Variation Example: (Catala.) A merchant (knight) goes on a journey (pilgrimage). He leaves his faithful wife alone & unsupervised. A young man falls in love with her, but she rejects his advances. Sick with love, he goes to an old woman (nun) who promises to help. The old woman gives her female dog nothing to eat for two days, & on the third day gives it food cooked with mustard (pepper), which makes its eyes water. The old woman (often disguised as a nun or dervish) takes this “weeping” dog with her to visit the wife whom the young man loves. When the wife asks what is the matter with the dog, the old woman at first does not reply. Then she tells the wife that the dog is actually her daughter (sister), who turn ed into an animal because she did not reciprocate a man’s love. The young wife believes this false story & asks the old woman to ar range a meeting for her with the young man. The go-between cannot find the lovesick young man but does not want to lose her payment for arranging the meeting. She meets a man (who happens to be the husband, returning home) & offers him an assignation. When the wife recognizes her husband, she berates him & accuses him of adulterous intentions. She pretends to have set up the situation as a test. Thus she is exonerated, her hus band is made to seem to be an adulterer, & the old woman loses her payment.

This tale exists chiefly in four different forms: (1) A dead man would rather remain in purgatory than return to his quarrelsome wife on earth (would rather not go to heaven because he does not want to be with his wife). (2) A shepherd compares his own sorry situation with the crucifixion: Christ suffered on the cross for only a few hours. Being mar-ried would have been a real punishment for him, especially if he had had children & no money to buy them presents for Easter. (3) An old man comes to the door of heaven & St. Peter asks him what he did on earth. He answers that he was married. Peter lets him come right in because he already suffered his time in purgatory. A second man, who overheard this exchange, also wants to enter heaven. He tells Peter that he was married twice. Peter tells him that there is no place in heaven for such fools. (4) A priest demands payment from a man for having performed his marriage. The man proposes that he “unmarry” him instead.
Misc. type. This type refers to a cycle of related tales & is not clearly specified.

A good-for-nothing young man from a poor family learns the craft of stealing & comes home as a master thief. He (his father) boasts about his skill in front of the earl (godfather), who demands (usually) three tests. (1) The master thief steals a horse (dog) out of a closely-guarded stall. He disguises himself as an old woman (beggar) & gives liquor (a drug) to the farmhands (guards, soldiers) to make them sleep. (2) He steals the bedcover (shirt) & wedding ring of the earl’s wife. He contrives that the earl shoots a corpse (straw man) & goes to bury the body. The thief tells the earl’s wife that the earl needs the blanket & ring for the corpse. (3) He traps the priest & the sexton in a sack & puts candles on the backs of crabs. The men take him for an angel & the lights for wandering souls. He carries the sack to the goose house (hangs it in the bell tower or chimney). After these tests, the master thief is banished from the country (pardoned, rewarded).

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A thief pretends to show how a horse can be stolen, but actually he steals the horse himself. In some variants something else is stolen (shoes, clothing, a watch, dishes, purse, meat, etc.) (2) In a German version the horse is stolen in a different way. A rider meets a poor beggar who asks him to retrieve his crutch, which a prankster (bad boy) had hung up in a tree. When the rider climbs the tree, the pretended cripple jumps on his horse & rides away.
A traveler (travelers) watches a man fishing in the street. The companions of the fisherman meanwhile rob the traveler’s wagon.

A master thief (apprentice) steals an ox (ram) of a farmer (farmhand) who is going to market. The thief drops first one, then the other, of a pair of matched objects (shoes, boots, sword & sheath, knife & fork) in the road. The farmer passes by the first object but, when he sees the second, he goes back for the first, leaving his animal behind. The thief takes the animal. Other tricks are also used to distract the farmer’s attention: the master thief pretends to hang himself in the forest (pretends to be dead). Or he imitates the cry of the farmer’s animal or sets a rabbit (chicken) free. In other variants one of the thieves takes the bell off a sheep that is following a donkey. He ties the bell to the donkey’s tail & steals the sheep. A second thief steals the donkey by offering to take care of it while the owner goes to look for his missing sheep.

Thieves (robbers) test their expertise through a contest in which they steal from each other. Or a new member of a band of robbers has to demonstrate his skill & outdoes his teacher. This tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) One thief steals an egg out of a bird’s nest without disturbing the bird. A second thief steals the same egg from the breast (pants pocket) of the first, or steals the trousers (shoe soles) off him while he climbs up to get the egg. Or the first thief takes off his cloth in or-der to get the egg, & the second thief steals the cloth. (2) Two thieves steal a ham (butchered hog, goat) from the wife of a former member of their band. This man steals the ham from them, & finally they steal it back again. (3) Two thieves trick each other. First, they exchange supposed-ly valuable sacks which turn out to contain only worthless things (sand, hay, etc.). Next, they exchange jobs (tending an un manageable cow, carrying water in a leaky pot, etc.) because each thinks the other’s work is easier, & both come to grief. Together they find (steal) a treasure & each tries to trick the other out of his share. One hides in a chest, & the other, believing it to be full of gold, carries it home.
A master thief, in order to vindicate himself & his deceased mother in the eyes of the king (his father), disguises himself (as Shiva, fakir, woman, etc.) & steals repeatedly from the king.

A boy (thief, boaster, fool, Eulenspiegel, couple) hides (falls asleep drunk) in an empty beehive. Two thieves come at night to steal the bees & weigh all the hives. Believing that the heaviest is the best, they carry off the one with the boy in it. He pulls the hair of one of them, who gets angry at his companion for bothering him. Then the boy pulls the hair of the other thief, who also blames his companion. The boy continues this until the thieves put down the hive to fight each other. In some variants the boy (man) does not bother the thieves. They take the hive & build a fire under it. When the boy cries out, they are frightened & run away.

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) An uncle & his nephew (grandfather & grandson, group of thieves) steal an ox (sheep) & roast it. The nephew (apprentice thief) wants to keep all the meat for himself. He takes the hide to a waterhole. Hiding in the bushes, he beats the hide as if he himself were being beaten. He cries & shouts that it was not he but his uncle  who stole the ox. The uncle thinks that the boy has been caught, so he runs away. In some variants the thieves cut the tail (head) off the ox (sheep) & stick it in the mouth (backside) of another, so that it looks as if one ox has eaten the other. Or they put the severed part in a swamp. When the owner swims out to get his drowned animal, they steal his clothes. (2) A boy (woman) tells a passing thief (soldier) that he has lost a silver cup (pail, etc.) in the well (river), & asks him to get it back for him. The thief takes off his clothes, climbs in the well, & finds nothing. When he comes back up, he finds that his clothes have been stolen.
A beggar manages to obtain alms from the same person three (twenty-one) times by wearing various disguises.

Two thieves steal something valuable (fur coat, crown, cup) & dispute over how to divide it. At night one of them climbs into the bedroom of the owner (judge, lord of the manor) & tells him what happened in his dream. The owner gives him a deci sion in his sleep as to who should keep the object. Meanwhile the second thief robs the storeroom (pantry) of the owner.

Classifications: Creditor Falsely Reported Insane When He Demands Money
Variation Example: A hard-hearted merchant sends an assistant several times to (unwarrant edly) collect payment from a debtor. The debtor reports that the assistant is mentally deranged. The man is locked in an abbey where he is treated with prayers & holy relics. He resists these measures & is beaten. The merchant forgives the debt when he is threatened with the same treatment.

Classifications: Theft Commited While Tale is Told
Variation Example: Two (three) thieves steal from a man (woman). While one of them accomplishes the theft, the other relates a tale that describes what is actually happening. With the victim thus distracted, his com-panion can work without being noticed. In another version, one thief performs a song (dance) that tells his companion where to find the booty.

A man (farmer) steals (secretly kills) a sheep (hog). He is denounced by a neighbor (owner) & has to hide the animal. He wraps it in clothing (cloth) & lays it in a cradle as if it were a (sick) baby (in bed as if it were his brother, sets it on a toilet). The police (authorities) come looking for the stolen animal, but do not recognize it. In some variants a living pig is hidden in a cradle & is discovered when it squeals. In other variants a farmer smuggles a slaughtered hog wearing his wife’s clothes through a guarded gate (a stolen sheep is dressed & propped up at the rudder of a boat.
A soldier weighs a stingy farmer (teaches him how to fish with a chisel). Meanwhile a companion of the soldier steals the farmer’s butter (fish).

Classifications: Two Thieves Married to the Same Woman
Variation Example: Two thieves (day & night thieves, burglar & pickpocket) are both married to the same woman. When they discover this, they fight over her. They go to a judge or to the woman who decides that they should have a contest to see which of them is the better thief, & he will keep the woman as his wife. In some variants, one (the less able) thief breaks into the bedroom of his ruler & tells him his story. The ruler decides that the woman should belong to this thief.

Two older brothers refuse to take their stupid youngest brother on their thieving expeditions. The youngest brother hurries out before them & arranges with their intended victim to be paid to guard his belongings against theft. When the older brothers break in, the youngest, without being recognized, beats them, & they return home empty-handed. This happens twice. The third time the brothers take the youngest with them. Instead of valu-ables, he carries off the owner’s door.
Misc. type with diverse variants.

Swindlers (thieves, Gypsies, female trickster) dress a beggar (foolish farmer) as a noble lord. (They take him to an inn & pretend to be his servants.) They steal from one or more merchants by saying that their master will pay for what they take (they say they will get money from their master). Leaving the man hostage in the inn or with the merchants, the swindlers leave with their spoils. The “noble” lord is discovered to be a beggar. He is either punished or permitted to leave.

Three (four) tricksters (thieves, students, soldiers) want some supper. They have no money, so they obtain their food through (three) successive tricks. Usually someone else has to pay for their food. In some variants a single trickster gets a free meal through one of various tricks, e.g. by pretending that he is an invited guest.

Two men (students, farmhands) in an inn look out of the window & see that the churchtower is lopsided. They wager as to which side the tower will fall toward, to east or to west. The loser has to pay for the meal (wine). They enjoy their meal. When later the innkeeper asks for the payment they tell him, he has to wait until the tower falls.
A master covers his farmhand (workman) with tar & feathers (honey & wool) & takes him to the robbers’ house. The robbers are frightened & run away, leaving their treasure behind.

Three travelers need a place to spend the night. After they are turned away by an innkeeper, one of them climbs up to the roof & stops the chimney with his coat, so that the inn fills with smoke. (The other guests leave and) the innkeeper lets the travelers stay there (for free).

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A boy in the forest comes upon a robber who takes his sword & robs him. The boy asks the robber to cut off his hand, to make it appear that the boy had fought to defend himself. When the robber swings the sword, the boy pulls his hand back & the sword be comes stuck in a tree trunk. The boy pulls the sword out & kills the robber. (2) A robber attacks a farmer (merchant) & takes his money. The victim asks the robber to shoot his hat (clothes) so that it will appear that the robber had to use considerable force. When the robber has used up all his ammunition, the farmer chases him away with his stick.

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A merchant is chasing a thief who stole from him. Disguised as a farmer, the thief stands by the side of the road pretending to be guarding a valuable falcon which he has hidden under his hat. When the merchant comes by, the “farmer” offers to chase the thief, if the merchant will guard the falcon & lend him his horse. The merchant pays him for helping, & the thief keeps the horse in addition. (2) A man defecates by the side of a road & covers the pile with his hat. When a priest comes by, the man explains that he has caught a beautiful bird. He sells the “bird” to the priest with the condition that he should not pick up the hat until the man is out of sight. After the man has left, the priest reaches under the hat to grasp the bird, & finds only a handful of feces.

A clever thief (student, beggar, traveling monk) steals a donkey (horse, mule, ox, cow) that had been tied up (to a tree or hedge, behind a wagon) or saddled or yoked. He leaves his compan-ion in place of the stolen animal. The companion convinces the owner (farmer, minister, pilgrim) that he had been turned into the animal as a punishment for his sins (for cursing his father or mother). The period of his punishment is now over & he has become human again. The owner of the animal believes this & lets him go free (and often apologizes for having beaten or insulted him, & gives him hospitality or money). The owner goes to buy a new donkey at the market, where he finds his old animal. Believing that this is his acquaintance, the owner reproaches him for having sinned again, & refuses to buy the animal.

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A gentleman agrees to exchange his good horse for the poor horse of a farmer, provided the farmer will eat its dung. The farmer does so & discovers valuables in the dung. (2) A gentleman (Englishman) agrees to give a farmer (Russian) a cow (his fortune) if the farmer will eat a frog. The farmer succeeds in eating half, & offers the other half to the gentleman to eat if he wants to keep the cow (the Russian fulfills the condition but the Englishman cannot; so he does not get back his fortune).
A farmer sells a gentleman (pope) a sheep (goat) which supposedly hunts wolves. The wolves devour the sheep.

A dupe puts his shoulder under a huge rock (tree, stationary animal) & pretends to hold it up. He persuades a passerby (fool, shepherd) to take his place (so he can go & get a drink of water) & then runs away with the passerby’s horse (belongings, animals).

A man has two (three) dogs with peculiar names, e.g. “Shepherd” & “Get-the-Stick”. When the man calls his dogs, a thief (thieves) believes he has been discovered & will be beaten (caught). He runs away.

A rich man (ruler) orders that a drunken farmer (a merchant who has been drugged into sleep) be brought into his house. He dresses him in fine clothes & feeds him well (and lets him perform the rich man’s duties). After a day (an hour, three years) the farmer is taken in his sleep back to his old house. He thinks he has been in heaven (has dreamed it all. He is no longer satisfied with his old position).

Two swindlers hear of a wealthy man who has died recently. One of them takes the dead man’s place & is buried (hides near the grave). The other finds the relatives of the dead man & tells them that the man had borrowed a large amount of money from him. Asking that they repay the money, he suggests that they verify the debt by asking the dead man. They do so & the confederate answers from his hiding place that the debt must be paid. The swindler who takes the money goes away, leaving his confederate still buried in the ground.

Classifications: The Wise Carving of the Fowl
Variation Example: This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A poor man (farmer, clever man) brings his master (ruler) a chicken (dove, goose, etc.) as a present. The master asks him to divide the bird appropriately among the members of his household. The poor man gives the master the head & his wife the neck, because the head & the neck belong together (the wife the rump, because she sits at home, or the heart). He gives the two sons the legs, because they work outside the house to support the household, & the two daughters the wings, because they will fly away. He takes the body for himself. The master rewards him well for his wisdom. Sometimes the tale continues: A neighbor hears of the poor man’s good fortune. He brings the master a present of five chickens along with rice. When he is asked to divide these appropriately he cannot do so, & he is beaten. (2) Sometimes as a conclusion to the version above: A master asks the poor man to divide (these) five chickens (other birds) among the members of his household. The poor man gives the master & his wife one bird, to make three. Likewise he gives one to the two sons & one to the two daughters. Finally he takes the last two for himself, to make another set of three.

Classifications: Hog's Head Divided According to Scripture
Variation Example: A clergyman, a sexton, & a schoolmaster (three students) want to divide a roasted pig (a pig’s head) among themselves. The criterion for the division is their skill in quoting Scripture. The minister cuts off an ear & says, “So Peter cut off an ear from the servant of the high priest”. The sexton cuts the head off the pig (the second ear) & says, “So was the head of John the Baptist cut off” (“and they gave him a box on the ear”). The schoolmaster considers for a long time. Finally he spreads a cloth & puts the rest of the pig (head) on it & says, “And then they took the holy body away”. In some variants, three monks find a single egg & agree that it should go to the one who gives the most appropriate quote from the Bible. The first says, “Purify it from the shell of falsehood”. The second says, “Sprinkle it with the salt of wisdom”. The third says, “Come in to praise the Lord!” & eats the egg.

A farmer’s son who is studying philosophy (medicine) has returned home. One day two eggs (fowls, pancakes) are served for dinner. In order to show off his education, he explains that these are not two but three: “This is one, that makes two, & together they are three”. His father refrains from contradicting him. He takes one egg for himself, gives the second to his wife, & invites his son to eat the third egg.

Classifications: The Clever Division of the Herd
Variation Example: A man (farmer, Turk, Arab) leaves his three sons (nephews, farmhands) a total of 17 cows (horses, camels, coins) to be divided as follows: the oldest son is to have half; the middle son, one third; & the youngest, one ninth. They are unable to solve this problem until a bystander adds one of his own animals to the herd. From 18 animals, each son can take his proper inheritance, & then the bystander takes his own animal back.

(The Decisions of Shemjaka.) A poor man (merchant, baker) causes a series of accidents: He pulls off the tail of a (borrowed) horse (one of two oxen that he has borrowed dies). The owner sues him. The poor man flees into a house & frightens (hits) a pregnant woman so that she miscarries. Or a woman invites him in out of the rain, & he sits on her sofa & accidentally kills her child. Her husband (the woman) sues him as well. Out of desperation, the poor man jumps from a high tower (bridge) & kills a passerby, whose brother (other relative) sues him. The injured parties bring the poor man before a judge. The judge decides as follows: The poor man should keep the borrowed horse until its tail grows back. He should impregnate the mother with another child (and her husband should hit her again, to give her another miscarriage). Her husband rejects this settlement & withdraws his suit. (In some variants, he has to pay a fine to the poor man.) The brother (other relative) of the killed man should jump from the tower upon the poor man in order to kill him. He also withdraws his suit. (In some variants he also has to pay a fine to the poor man.) (The poor man leaves with the horse & his settlements.) Some variants have a frame tale: The judge persuades a baker (merchant) to give him a goose (duck) that belongs to someone else. He promises to protect him if the owner of the goose accuses him of theft. Then as above.

Classifications: The Innocent Man Condmened to Death
Variation Example: A holy man & his disciple come to a city where the king & all his ministers are fools, & where all kinds of food are sold for the same price. The holy man leaves at once & warns his disciple to do so too, but the disciple stays despite the warning. A thief tries to break into a house at night but is killed when the wall collapses (he puts his eye out on a projecting stick). The house-holder is called before the king & sentenced to death (to have his eye put out). The householder, however, blames the mason who built the wall who, in turn, blames the man who supplied the mortar, etc., until finally one man is found who is too stupid to find someone else to blame. He is condemned to death. The owner explains that he needs both his eyes for his work, but his neighbor, who is a hunter, needs only one. The hunter says he really needs both eyes, but his neighbor, who is a musician, always closes his eyes when he plays, etc. The king decrees that one of his eyes be put out. The condemned man is too thin to fit the stake (noose). The disciple is chosen to be executed in his place. The holy man returns & announces that he has discovered that the next man to be executed will go directly to heaven. The king leaps upon the stake himself.
